<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_add_page_size:
```c
static int metal_add_page_size(const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags)
{
	int index = _metal.num_page_sizes;
	unsigned long size = 1UL << shift;

	if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - overflow\n",
			  size);
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	}

	if (!path || shift <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - invalid args\n",
			  size);
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_shift = shift;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_size = size;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].mmap_flags = mmap_flags;
	strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
	_metal.num_page_sizes++;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "added page size %ld @%s\n", size, path);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation — the strncpy call is reachable when the prior checks (index < MAX_PAGE_SIZES and path != NULL and shift > 0) pass. There is no unreachable code introduced by this statement. (Note: strncpy may not NUL-terminate if path length >= PATH_MAX, which is a separate correctness/safety issue but not a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.)
